  17. (**************************************************************************)

  19. [@@@alert unstable
  20.     "The Domain interface may change in incompatible ways in the future."
  21. ]

  23. (** Domains.

  25.     See 'Parallel programming' chapter in the manual.

  27.     @since 5.0 *)

  29. ‌type !'a t
  30. (** A domain of type ['a t] runs independently, eventually producing a
  31.     result of type 'a, or an exception *)

  33. ‌val spawn : (unit -> 'a) -> 'a t
  34. (** [spawn f] creates a new domain that runs in parallel with the
  35.     current domain.

  37.     @raise Failure if the program has insufficient resources to create another
  38.     domain. *)

  40. ‌val join : 'a t -> 'a
  41. (** [join d] blocks until domain [d] runs to completion. If [d] results in a
  42.     value, then that is returned by [join d]. If [d] raises an uncaught
  43.     exception, then that is re-raised by [join d]. *)

  45. ‌type id = private int
  46. (** Domains have unique integer identifiers *)

  48. ‌val get_id : 'a t -> id
  49. (** [get_id d] returns the identifier of the domain [d] *)

  51. ‌val self : unit -> id
  52. (** [self ()] is the identifier of the currently running domain *)

  54. ‌val before_first_spawn : (unit -> unit) -> unit
  55. (** [before_first_spawn f] registers [f] to be called before the first domain
  56.     is spawned by the program. The functions registered with
  57.     [before_first_spawn] are called on the main (initial) domain. The functions
  58.     registered with [before_first_spawn] are called in 'first in, first out'
  59.     order: the oldest function added with [before_first_spawn] is called first.

  61.     @raise Invalid_argument if the program has already spawned a domain. *)

  63. ‌val at_exit : (unit -> unit) -> unit
  64. (** [at_exit f] registers [f] to be called when the current domain exits. Note
  65.     that [at_exit] callbacks are domain-local and only apply to the calling
  66.     domain. The registered functions are called in 'last in, first out' order:
  67.     the function most recently added with [at_exit] is called first. An example:

  69.     {[
  70. let temp_file_key = Domain.DLS.new_key (fun _ ->
  71.   let tmp = snd (Filename.open_temp_file "" "") in
  72.   Domain.at_exit (fun () -> close_out_noerr tmp);
  73.   tmp)
  74.     ]}

  76.     The snippet above creates a key that when retrieved for the first
  77.     time will open a temporary file and register an [at_exit] callback
  78.     to close it, thus guaranteeing the descriptor is not leaked in
  79.     case the current domain exits. *)

  81. ‌val cpu_relax : unit -> unit
  82. (** If busy-waiting, calling cpu_relax () between iterations
  83.     will improve performance on some CPU architectures *)

  85. ‌val is_main_domain : unit -> bool
  86. (** [is_main_domain ()] returns true if called from the initial domain. *)

  88. ‌val recommended_domain_count : unit -> int
  89. (** The recommended maximum number of domains which should be running
  90.     simultaneously (including domains already running).

  92.     The value returned is at least [1]. *)

  94. module DLS : sig
  95. (** Domain-local Storage *)

  97.     type 'a key
  98.     (** Type of a DLS key *)

  100.     val new_key : ?split_from_parent:('a -> 'a) -> (unit -> 'a) -> 'a key
  101.     (** [new_key f] returns a new key bound to initialiser [f] for accessing
  102. ,        domain-local variables.

  104.         If [split_from_parent] is not provided, the value for a new
  105.         domain will be computed on-demand by the new domain: the first
  106.         [get] call will call the initializer [f] and store that value.

  108.         If [split_from_parent] is provided, spawning a domain will
  109.         derive the child value (for this key) from the parent
  110.         value. This computation happens in the parent domain and it
  111.         always happens, regardless of whether the child domain will
  112.         use it.
  113.         If the splitting function is expensive or requires
  114.         child-side computation, consider using ['a Lazy.t key]:

  116.         {[
  117.         let init () = ...

  119.         let split_from_parent parent_value =
  120.           ... parent-side computation ...;
  121.           lazy (
  122.             ... child-side computation ...
  123.           )

  125.         let key = Domain.DLS.new_key ~split_from_parent init

  127.         let get () = Lazy.force (Domain.DLS.get key)
  128.         ]}

  130.         In this case a part of the computation happens on the child
  131.         domain; in particular, it can access [parent_value]
  132.         concurrently with the parent domain, which may require
  133.         explicit synchronization to avoid data races.
  134.     *)

  136.     val get : 'a key -> 'a
  137.     (** [get k] returns [v] if a value [v] is associated to the key [k] on
  138.         the calling domain's domain-local state. Sets [k]'s value with its
  139.         initialiser and returns it otherwise. *)

  141.     val set : 'a key -> 'a -> unit
  142.     (** [set k v] updates the calling domain's domain-local state to associate
  143.         the key [k] with value [v]. It overwrites any previous values associated
  144.         to [k], which cannot be restored later. *)

  146. end
